data.title: Remembering Chauncey Billups' homecoming
data.meta_description: Although he won his only NBA title in Detroit, Chauncey Billups' return to Denver in the latter part of his career was a significant moment.
data.text:
The most significant aspect of his return to Denver was the 2008-09 season, the best season in franchise history.

Billups had been moved around a lot in his career, previously having stints in Boston, Toronto, Denver (the first time), Minnesota and most notably, Detroit where he won an NBA title and was named Finals MVP in 2004.

November 3, 2008 will always be remembered as an interesting day in the history of two franchises, the Denver Nuggets and the Detroit Pistons.

Allen Iverson joined the Pistons in a blockbuster trade, while Billups went the other way to Denver.

Billups came to Detroit as a once promising player who hadn't realised his potential, he left as an All-Star, an NBA champion, a Finals MVP and an elite defender with a propensity for knocking down big shots.

He also left with an apt nickname, Mr Big Shot!

That trade in 2008 will always be viewed in a number of ways.

Denver acquired Billups as a steadying influence to propel a promising young roster, Detroit acquired Iverson in rebuild mode with one potential run in them.

That run didn't eventuate in Detroit.

For Denver, the young core certainly propelled to a higher level.

It wasn't easy for Detroit to pull the trigger on trading their leader.

Pistons GM Joe Dumars said it was "the hardest and toughest" move he had made as a general manager.

Things clicked for Denver in the 2008-09 season, reaching the conference finals for the first time since 1985.

Billups averaged 17.9 points and 6.4 assists.

They were just two wins away from a finals berth.

For Billups, it was his seventh straight conference finals appearance, a remarkable feat.

The Pistons? They went in the other direction, failing to win a playoff series since.

The Nuggets won 54 games (matching the most wins for the franchise since their induction in the NBA), earning them the second seed in the Western Conference (the highest the team had ever been seeded for the playoffs).

The Nuggets eliminated the New Orleans Hornets in the first round in five games.

During that series, Billups set a Nuggets franchise record with eight three-pointers in a playoff game.

Against the Hornets, he averaged 22.6 points, 7.4 assists and 3.8 three-pointers made.

Denver then eliminated Dallas in five games before setting up a conference finals meeting with the Lakers.

The Nuggets had a second half lead in each of the first five games, but won just two of them.

They would eventually fall in six games to the eventual champions.

Still to this day, it's the closest the Nuggets have been to an NBA championship.

While Billups had the best intentions to retire as a Nugget, he was traded to New York in 2011 as part of the Carmelo Anthony trade.

A move that was met with disdain from the Denver fans.

While things ended badly, Billups and the Nuggets will always look back fondly on that 2008-09 season.

The Nuggets were always viewed as a good team led by Anthony.

They weren't viewed as a great team because they continually struggled to make it out of the first round of the playoffs.

That changed when Billups and his tremendous leadership arrived.

Players were instantly held accountable, on both ends of the floor.

Carmelo was forced to play a team game and sacrifice some of his offence to help on the defensive end.

There were a number of individuals that Billups had to keep in check.

The likes of Anthony, Kenyon Martin and JR Smith.

He managed to do that while playing at an extraordinary high level.

There's no question that he became the leader as soon as he walked through the door.

As we look back on a great career, so much of the coverage will be of Billups' championship and success in Detroit, and it should be.

But you can make the case that the greatest achievement was turning an underachieving franchise into a winner.
